In my opinion, you should test every public method of a class.  The
reason I have for this is that even though you know that the method
turns around and calls another method that is tested somewhere else,
that may not always be the case, and you don't know that the call is
coded correctly either, or that the underlying class/method hasn't been
changed to return something that is unexpected.  So even though you have
an action called login/logoff that may turn right around and call
login/logoff on another class that has been tested properly, I'd at
least test that the call is accomplished appropriately and the results
are correct.  
 
IMHO Yes and no to more tests = better software.   You can create a
bunch of tests that don't actually test anything (writing an object
creation test that asserts not null for example instead of testing that
the object is correct) that won't make better software.  However, more
proper tests definitely improve your software maintenance and can catch
errors that only occur once in a blue moon.  That said, it's almost
impossible to test every condition, which is why when an error occurs
the first thing you do is write a test for it so you can be fairly sure
it can't happen again.
